Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Industrial Chemicals Corporation (ICC) is a small business engaged in the wholesale distribution of bulk chemicals.  They have operated at the Arvada facility since 1971 with an excellent safety record.  Although ICC handles a number of chemicals, only ethyl ether  and piperidine are covered under the Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  ICC's Emergency Response Plan and overall Risk Management Plan were developed in the early 1990s for the entire facility, and ICC's RMP for ethyl ether and piperidine are based on these existing plans.

Piperidine is delivered from the supplier in 44,000-pound loads in an over-the-road tanker truck to the ICC facility.  After inspection, the piperidine is transferred under nitrogen pressure to a dedicated, 3-compartment ICC tanker truck.  The dedicated tanker truck is held on site until the customer requests delivery.  ICC delivers one compartment full (about 1850 gallons) to the customer and returns the partially filled tanker truck to the ICC facility.  Deliveries continue until the trailer is empty, at which time the dedicated tanker truck is ready to receive another bulk shipment from the supplier. Trailer is parked on diked concrete containment area and is sealed and secured. Smaller quantities may be drummed for longer term storage.

Ethyl ether is delivered in tank trucks containing approximately 7,500 gallons (45,000 lb).  These tank trucks are parked overnight at the unloading area and are unloaded into 55-gallon drums for delivery to customers.  The empty tanker is removed the same day unloading is completed.  Drums of ethyl ether are stored on site in a refrigerated storage trailer or in a sprinkled warehouse.  All transfers are conducted in accordance with industry-recommended equipment, and there has never been an incident involving ethyl ether at the ICC facility.

ICC has installed a number of passive and active safety controls to promote the safe handling of ethyl ether.  These measures include extensive concrete diking

to stop the flow of any ether spilled during transfer and detailed written procedures describing transfer operations and emergency responses.  Large quantiteis of absorbent are always stored on site at ICC in the event of a spill in the diked area.

Emergency Response to the ICC facility is coordinated by Southwest Adams County Fire Protection District.  They are the first responders and are responsible for calling in Adams County HazMat and other supporting organizations if needed.  They also provide incident command in the event of a large spill or fire.

Risk management and emergency preparedness was a part of ICC's operations long before the RMP rule was published.  ICC's proactive attitued towards Risk management is reflected in the facility design, the operating procedures, the cooperation with local responders, and the employee's attitudes.  This RMP summarizes the existing Emergency Response and Risk Management plans at ICC.  

On September 25, 2003, ICC completed modifications to the facility to come into compliance with HM 232 which requires design and implementation of a Site Security Plan.  ICC's HM 232 implementation was reviewed by the Department of Transportation in January, 2004.  The ICC site continues to operate in accordance with the requirements of HM 232.  On June 8, 2006, ICC successfully completed a NACD third-party audit under the Responsible Distribution Process Verification (RDPV).
